title: Wednesday, 13th July, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

New era in British politics

PM

Personified by this chap

11:01 am
PM

PM

Tim Martin of 'Spoons, of course

PM

Suppose he does sort of speak for the disaffected white working class

11:02 am
PM

Anyway, he's certainly shared his thoughts this morning

PM

"As most people will be aware, an unusual number of forecasts for the UK economy have been made in the run-up to, and the aftermath of, the referendum. Most of the forecasts from representatives of institutions which are normally responsible for financial stability were extremely negative.

PM

"For example, the International Monetary Fund`s Christine Lagarde said in May that a leave vote in the referendum would be "pretty bad to very, very bad."

11:03 am
PM

He goes on to name all the usual suspects

PM

Carney

PM

Osborne etc

11:03 am
PM

All here:

PM

http://www.investe...1607130700070036E/

BE

Great.

11:03 am
PM

And

PM

"Unbeknown to most voters, one of the "architects" of the Remain campaign, which devised the above approach, was Peter Mandelson ("How the struggle for Europe was lost", Peter Mandelson, Financial Times, 2 July), who worked closely with Cameron, Osborne and others

PM

"In my opinion, the above individuals and organisations are either dishonest, or they have a poor understanding of economics, since democracy and prosperity are closely linked and the EU is clearly undemocratic. By voting to restore democracy in the UK, I believe the UK's economic prospects will improve, although it is quite possible that the unprecedented and irresponsible doom-mongering, outlined above, may lead to some kind of slowdown.

11:04 am
PM

But he's forced to be cautious, trading wise

PM

"In spite of the dire warnings above, Wetherspoon trade strengthened slightly in recent weeks and we consequently anticipate a modestly improved outcome for this financial year. Caution should be exercised in extrapolating current levels of sales growth for future years."

PM

Meanwhile, there's some discussion this morning about how those working at a former newspaper have a poor understanding of how finance works

11:05 am
PM

See this tweet

PM

https://twitter.com/TedJeory/status/752956314502955008

PM

Story here: http://www.indepen...rris-a7133231.html

11:06 am
PM

I was going on about this yesterday -- how we've gone 'post-truth'

PM

Fact is he's a client relationship manager for Capital Group

PM

Evil business of pensions

11:07 am
PM

Frances has a good pop at the matter here: http://www.forbes....ster/#1f26ee23bed9

undefined
PM

The pipe of post_Brexit strategy notes has opened up again

11:08 am
PM

Inbox full of them

PM

Will try and do another usual place bundle later, since those are obv v popular

PM

But for now...

11:08 am
PM

Bryce --w hat do you reckon

PM

Krona back to looking like a krona

PM

Housebuilders heading back down

11:09 am
PM

Certainly those focused on London

PM

Banks under the cosh

PM

Plenty of trading statements

11:09 am
PM

All similarly cautious

PM

What do we say?

BE

Well, what do we say?

11:10 am
PM

omg smile

BE

The FTSE remains locked to its 11-month high. The fact that cable isn't pinging up and down by 2% a day any more might be a quite significant factor in that.

BE

Trading wise, it does feel we're in a kind of purgatory now.

11:11 am
PM

Purgatory

PM

You've got it

PM

11:12 am
BE

None of the companies reporting can say that they've felt any post-Brexit effects because ..... well, the speed of peoples' behaviour doesn't adjust that quickly.

BE

But every single one of them has to say either "we're cautious about confidence after blah blah" or "hooray for sterling crapping out, but we're still cautious about confidence after blah blah."

BE

On that theme, housebuiders? The ultimate "everything's fine -- for now!" stocks.

11:14 am
PM

Sure

Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 399.90, down 13.4 (-3.24%), High: 416.40, Low: 385.10, Volume: 5.38m
BE

Essentially saying nothing.

11:14 am
BE

No new market commentary.

BE

After FY matches expectations.

BE

Management making cautious noises but nothing quantitative.

11:15 am
BE

That -- that! -- is worth 3% off the sector.

BE

Let me get some Deutsche to summarise what was said.

BE

Reporting a pre tax profit stronger than anytime in past decade and net cash of
£590m, Barratt FY 16 results are ahead of DB ests, However with uncertainty
over the outlook for the UK and housebuilding post Brexit we believe the
market will be blinkered, focusing only on trading in the ‘new world’. Over the
past days the share price of Barratt has bounced significantly. However,
trading at 1.07x calendarised 2017 NTAV, and with a 7.1% dividend yield
(mostly received in November), we believe the stock remains oversold BUY.

11:17 am
PM

7% yield?

BE

Yep. 7% divi, from a company that can run on empty and just eat its own landbank for three years. I'm not thinking that's bad value, even if it's quite silly in normal circumstances to buy a housebuilder into a recession.

BE

With the benefit of H2 16 average selling price +6% on our forecasts, Barratt
reported H2 16 revenues 7% ahead of DB ests. While EBIT margin doesn’t
appear to have shown the progression as much progression as hoped (+0.5ppt
YoY for FY 16), higher profit from the joint ventures (£72m vs guidance of
£60m) implies profit before tax approx 1% ahead of our forecasts. Reflecting
primarily the contribution of the additional completions towards the end of FY
16, but also higher land creditors (reaching 38% of land approvals), Barratt
reported net cash of c£590m, substantially ahead of the £300-350m guidance.
The group reports a 2ppt increase in its ROCE to 27%.

11:18 am
BE

Within its statement Barratt provides no update on trading post Brexit, and we
believe management will only comment on data points such as reservations, site
and website visitors, cancellations etc at the time of the FY 16 results in Sep. The
group reports net private reservations per outlet per week in H2 16 of 0.72 (2015:
0.70), and average of 365 active outlets (2015: 380). This has driven a forward
order book +18.7% to £1.6bn in value terms, +8.6% in volumes (largely flat
when including joint ventures we believe reflecting the type and timing of
developments in London). As expected the statement contains no guidance for
FY 17 (although its medium term targets were for at least 25% ROCE in FY 17).

PM

Credit Suisse doing a little bit of knife catching also

PM

But i think they are still leery of Berekely etc

11:19 am
PM

Anything London focused

PM

There's a bit sector rejig note out from CS

PM

Let me find the bit\

11:19 am
PM

Housebuilders: upgrade to benchmark
We see five supports for this sector:
1. Elements of valuation
We believe that the appropriate valuation parameter for the homebuilders is book value
(largely because they have a relatively short asset life). The P/B of UK housebuilders
relative to both US homebuilders and the market is now back to neutral levels, and the P/B
once we adjust for understatement of book value (because book value did not rise as
much as the normal relationship with house prices suggested) is close again to average
levels.

PM

The yield relative of the sector has also picked up sharply back to historic average levels.
Looking at the long-run relative performance of the sector, around half of its
outperformance since 2012 has now been given up.

PM

2. The sector seems to be discounting a 5% fall in house prices in the UK and
around 9% in London
If we look at the RICs survey, ex London or mortgage approvals they are both consistent
with a small fall in house prices of around 5% nationally, with Berkeley Group, the Londonfocused
homebuilder, apparently discounting an even greater fall in prices in London.

11:20 am
PM

9% fall in London just doesnt sound enough to me

PM

The problem is that when house prices fall in nominal and real terms, they typically fall by
a lot more. Real declines in house prices have tended to last, on average, around 3 years
and in real terms house prices have fallen by around 23%.

PM

We don’t think house prices will fall by as much as they normally do. Historically, to get a
major correction in housing you have needed overvaluation, rising rates and a decline in
employment. Currently, overvaluation is apparent only in London and the South East (as
we discuss below), and the cost of servicing a mortgage continues only to decline. That
said, employment does seem likely to fall.

11:20 am
PM

■ Outside London, valuations are not stretched
Data from Halifax suggests that while the house price to earnings ratio in London is now
over 10x (having previously peaked in 2007 at around 6.5x), outside London valuations
are not yet back to previous peaks. In the North of England, the house price earnings/ratio
is at 4.3x, down from a peak in 2007 of around 6x.

PM

According to data from Lendinvest, yields outside London remain attractive when
compared to mortgage rates. Rental yields range from 4.8% in Yorkshire to 5.2% in the
North East and 5.4% in Birmingham, which we would consider attractive against an
average 2 year fixed rate mortgage rate of 1.9%.
On a national basis, the RICS sales to stock ratio (which leads house prices by c.6
months) is consistent with a rise in house prices and the Nationwide RICS survey with
inventory being particularly low.

PM

■ Interest payments as a percentage of income continue to fall
To get forced sellers you need employment to decline, rates to go up or banks to call in
defaulted mortgages. We doubt the latter two would be allowed to happen. Interest
payments as a percentage of income continue to fall. Prior to the 20% decline in property
prices in 2007-09, interest payments accounted for c.18% of income. Now, that figure is
below 8%.
■ Falling house prices have tended to be associated with falls in employment
Historically, employment has tended to lag the housing cycle. We can see though that
employment would need to contract by c0.5% a year to get a fall in house prices.

11:21 am
PM

Last block quickly

PM

3. In the long run, this is an undisrupted sector
Not only are there few alternatives to housing (although homes have been made in China
with 3D printers) but UK housing demand is almost permanently above supply. The UK
needs around 220K homes a year yet this year only around 155K homes will be built.
Indeed, every year since 1974 (outside London), supply has been below the required
demand. Moreover, the quoted players have increased their market share to almost 50%
which means that they are now much more disciplined and as our analysts, Harry Goad
and Samuel Thomas, point out, they are building 21% less homes than they were in 2009.
4. The government will likely try to support housing outside of London
The Help to Buy scheme for new build (which has accounted for c40% of new builds) has
already been extended to 2021 and we think it is quite possible that the funding for lending
scheme could be expanded. We suspect that the Help to Buy Scheme for existing homes
will be extended.
5. Short and long term price momentum
The sector is around 1 standard deviation oversold.

PM

More on that later in the usual place

11:22 am
BE

I think 9% looks reasonable for London, providing you remember what they're talking about.

BE

Average London house price is £472,264.

BE

Average Central London house price is three times that. £1,364,805.

11:22 am
PM

hmm, fair enough

BE

Clearly, one of those is an absurd bubble running on different financial mechanics than the other.

BE

Average out the two deratings, which will happen for entirely different reasons, and get 9%.

11:23 am
BE

Seems reasonable to me.

undefined
PM

So Burberry!

11:24 am
PM

Flying macs

Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,270, up 67 (+5.57%), High: 1,275, Low: 1,227, Volume: 1.72m
PM

Q1 here http://www.investe...1607130700070008E/

11:24 am
BE

"Hooray for sterling crapping out, but we're still cautious about confidence after blah blah," says Mr Bailey.

BE

(I'm paraphrasing, obviously.)

BE

What we get its -3% LFL.

11:25 am
BE

Which is slightly better than expectations, albeit with the caveat that expectations have come down a lot.

PM

(Boncoeur -- i think one of my daughters has control of my vote and she's very much a feminist...)

BE

SocGen can take us through the moving parts here.

11:26 am
BE

1) Sales: the retrenchment strategy (one brand,
20% fewer SKUs, capex guidance cut to £150m from £180m, low selling
space growth, stalled product diversification, merged men’s/women’s shows)
is not likely to boost growth above the sector as targeted. 2) Margin: opex
was cut by only half the level needed to reach the sector average, and this
was offset by reinvestment and reinstated bonuses, reflecting an opex floor,
given its sector-low capital intensity.

BE

Cutting a fifth of stock items and simplifying the brand range ..... Well, it worked for Tesco.

BE

And they're quite similar businesses, right? Burberry and Tesco?

11:27 am
PM

hehehe

BE

And Barclays.

BE

Burberry kicked off the luxury reporting season with a better than expected
performance. Like for likes fell -3% in a quarter that rose 6% in 2015/16 with the
group seeing significantly easier comps from this point. The group saw improving
sales of its fashion product – in line with the strategy to focus more on newness. It
remains all change at Burberry with a new CEO – Marco Gobbetti – arriving from
Celine during 2017 who will provide retail experience to help close the store density
discount to peers and a new COO/CFO Julie Brown from Smith and Nephew who will
provide experience in the restructuring of the operations in line with the business
plan set out at the FY16 results. We have cut forecasts by £20m to account for our
FX estimate falling from £110m to £90m, raised annual like for likes from -2% to -
1% but increased the wholesale decline by 1% to -11%. We retain the 1220p PT and
EW rating.

11:28 am
BE

Q1 17 lfl down 3%: Q1 17 organic growth came in flat against Barclays -3% and
consensus -4%, made up of lfl sales down -3% (Barclays and consensus -4.5%, range -
7 to -1%) offset by new space growth +3% (Barclays +1.5%). FX was a +4% translation
tailwind (Barclays +4.4%), bringing Q1 retail reported sales growth to +4% (Barclays
+1.4%) with £423m of sales against Barclays at £413m.

BE

All regions see lfl decline: In Asia Pacific, HK improved slightly from Q4 but was still
down double digits in lfl. Mainland China was unchanged, and Japan saw weaker
trading from tourists offset by stronger locals. Within EMEIA, UK improved in the last
week of Q1, resulting in up MSD overall. Continental Europe saw a double-digit decline
from tourists, especially in France and Italy, offset partially by growth in domestic
customers. Americas remained relatively weak with uneven demand from local clients
and double-digit declines in tourist shopping.

BE

£90m FY17 EBIT benefit from FX: The overall FX transactional benefit is now guided to
£90m for retail/wholesale (vs. c£50m in May, Barclays £90m from c£110m previously).
Otherwise guidance was unchanged aside from Wholesale expected to decline more
than 10% (Barclays -12% from -10% previously)

11:29 am
PM

Any discussion of the new incoming boss?

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

PM

Marco

11:29 am
BE

Not much I've seen, apart from the initial response.

BE

Which said, "sensible and necessary"

BE

Morgan Stanley's Burberry's house broker, and seems quite keen not to offend anyone.

11:30 am
BE

Christopher Bailey to become President and Chief Creative Officer. De-
coupling the CEO and Creative roles we think is a positive, allowing
Christopher Bailey to dedicate focus on the product offering, which is
important in the current low growth environment. This is a busy year at
Burberry - management has already announced its intention to reduce the
number of SKUs by 20% to streamline the product offering and is moving to
one label (combining the current three product labels) by year end (calendar).
Burberry is also a leader in its digital offering, which has been under the
direction of Christopher Bailey – we expect this will remain a key focus for him.

BE

You'll be so busy after your demotion, Mr Bailey!

BE

The announcement of a new combined CFO and COO role is particularly
positive, we think. Julie Brown has been appointed to the new role of Chief
Operating and Financial Officer. She will join from Smith & Nephew where she
is currently CFO. Bringing someone to the leadership team from a non-luxury
background is positive in our view and has the potential to take a more metric
driven attitude to performance. She has a background of delivering cost saving
and restructuring programs and this is likely to be taken positively by Burberry
investors given the current margin structure, which lags behind peers.

11:31 am
BE

Potential for a strong combination, but investors will need to be
patient. This looks like a well-balanced team structure – we like the
combination of the new CEO's luxury experience and the CFO/COO who is
external to the luxury industry. This has the potential to create a healthy
balance between investment in the brand and shareholder returns long term.
However, investors will need to be patient – Marco Gobbetti will join in 2017
'as soon as he is contractually able to do' so, which could take 12 months. Julie
Brown is expected to join Burberry in early 2017.

PM

We should see what the new chap looks like

PM

11:31 am
BE

(@Rushian: relatively, perhaps. though still only five paragraphs.)

PM

And Julia Brown

PM

11:32 am
BE

Cazenove too, on the management rejig. Since we're here.

BE

Burberry was facing challenges: a new lower growth luxury paradigm,
a tougher competitive landscape (not least the regained momentum of
Gucci over which Burberry had gained share in recent years a the
perceived 'coolest' luxury RTW brand to Millennials), a focus on
increasing sales densities at directly operated stores, the need to sustain
investments in digital, and to control and curb costs. As Burberry's LFL
outperformance came to an abrupt end some quarters back it became
clear that these challenges were intensifying and the plan to revert course
and resume with growth (laid out recently in a three year plan) likely
required critical management hires.

BE

I'm sure there's a chart somewhere of the perceived 'coolest' luxury RTW brands to Millennials, and I never want to see it.

11:33 am
undefined
BE

And at the opposite end of the retail spectrum .....

Poundland Group PLC (PLND:LSE): Last: 220.50, up 24.5 (+12.50%), High: 221.25, Low: 219.50, Volume: 16.92m
11:34 am
PM

Kronaland

BE

Note, it's not trading through the terms.

BE

Some people getting confused this morning, failing to spot you get a 2p dividend as well.

11:35 am
BE

So, yeah, this looks done. Over. Finished.

PM

Suspect people are lucky to get out

PM

Hasn't this business suffered an immediate heavy blow from sterling?

11:35 am
PM

it buys all its tat from the far east, surely

BE

Well ....... this is a theme I feel we're underplaying.

BE

No, it doesn't. It buys quite a lot of its rubbish from UK companies that have gone to the wall.

11:37 am
BE

Or are in deep distress, at least. Hence the random brands and stuff.

BE

For a company like Tiger, which is the Ikea of pound shops, sterling's going to be problematic.

BE

For Poundland, sterling's only going to be a secondary effect.

11:38 am
BE

Maybe.

BE

(@JL: have I been made CEO of Poundland? I wish someone had told me.)

BE

Here's Credit Suisse.

11:38 am
BE

■ Final offer agreed at 222p: Steinhoff and Poundland’s boards have
announced that they have reached an agreement on the terms of a cash
offer for the issued share capital of Poundland. At 222p per share, which is a
combination of 220p cash and 2p final dividend, this values Poundland at
£0.6bn, an EV/EBITDA multiple of 9x and a 12m PER of 16x. This comes
after Steinhoff built up a 23.6% stake in the business and its earlier cash
offer was rejected by the Poundland Board in June. Note that the sterling
weakness since the initial offer also would have helped Steinhoff's proposal.
The transaction is expected to completed by mid-September and is subject to
approval by 75% of Poundland’s shareholders other than Steinhoff, as well
court approval.
■ A fair price: We previously suggested 235p as the minimum exit price for
the business, based on a c3.5% operating margin next year on c£1.68bn
sales. The 222p seems a fair price given market conditions, the post Brexit
uncertainty and poor trading performance at Poundland.
■ Positive for Steinhoff: Whilst the transaction value amounts to less than 4%
of Steinhoff’s market capitalisation, we believe it represents an important
further step in supporting the group’s credentials as a broad-based large cap
discount retailer. Under Andy Bond, we believe this acquisition accelerates
Pepkor’s UK growth in a new (for Pep), but familiar category, with significant
potential for the group also in Europe and, potentially South Africa. Based on
our FY17 Poundland estimates (2.8% operating margin) and assuming 3%
funding costs, we estimate the transaction to be 1.8% EPS accretive to
Steinhoff. Assuming a 3.5% margin increases this to 2.6%. Reducing central
costs by £5-10m as part of a larger group, potentially adds a further 30-
60bps to the operating margin.

BE

And Canaccord.

BE

At a 220p share price, the shares stand on a cal 16 PER of 19.9x and 15.6x for cal 17,
with corresponding EV/EBITDA metrics of 9.2x and 7.4x. Excluding the 99p Store losses
reported in FY16, which we include above the line, rather than as an exceptional, would
change the cal 16 PER to 18.0x. The wider General Retail sector currently stands on a
cal 16 PER of 13.5x, falling to 12.5x for cal 17.

11:40 am
BE

And Liberum, who upgrade somewhat belatedly.

BE

Steinhoff already speak for 23.6% of the company and in addition to the cash offer have maintained the 2p dividend to be paid on 23 September who are on the register on 9 September. In our view this is a knock-out price and it was our view that significant downside risk existed if a bid did not materialise. Hence we move from SELL to HOLD and feel this should be seen as a very good result for PLND shareholders. The take out price equates to a March 2017E PE 21.6x and EV/EBITDA of 10.4x.

BE

........ while taking the opportunity to push B&M.

11:40 am
BE

Applying the same PE multiple for B&M (BUY, TP 300p) suggests a TP of 320p which suggests 27% upside from current levels. Poundland has a depreciation charge some 40% of EBITDA while B&M has a more normalised depreciation charge equating to c10% of EBITDA hence there is an EV/EBITDA comparison distortion.

Our 300p TP implies 16% upside, modestly below the long-term PE average of 21.9x. Our TP is a blended average of DCF of 240p and ROIC/WACC of 360p

Our forecasts for B&M suggest:

£315m of FCF to be generated over the next three years,
£170m of dividends to be paid over the next three years, suggesting debt will fall rapidly,
FCF dividend cover of 1.5x is very comfortable
Net debt/EBITDA of 2x is comfortable which should support additional cash returns. This is even after taking into account the c.£70-80m of capex on its store opening programme p.a,
Hence B&M can afford to increase cash returns in the region of £100m
B&M is one of the highest quality names in the retail landscape. It has a superior disruptive multi-price model which should in a period of uncertainty lead to out-performance. The group has a strong track record of managing exogenous shocks and while we take a prudent view to forecasts, there are multiple levers for these to be beaten. Simplistically, B&M benefits from higher ATVs in more prosperous times while footfall and volumes rise as consumers trade down in a more uncertain climate. Historically, the group has managed to offset FX headwinds through supply renegotiations, product and line optimisation and utilise pricing where it has a structural advantage / opportunity to do so. This multi-pronged approach across multiple categories and multiple price points is a powerful combination to support margins and mitigate potential headwinds.

B&M European Value Retail SA (BME:LSE): Last: 259.10, up 1.5 (+0.58%), High: 261.90, Low: 258.40, Volume: 487.03k
undefined
11:41 am
PM

Given our Japanese ownership

PM

We should mention that Emperor Akihito has had enough

PM

he wants to abdicate, Joseph has just informed

11:42 am
PM

PM

Sorry, image doesnt work

BE

Sayonara, Akihito.

11:42 am
PM

That's a bad fail on my part

PM

http://www.bloombe...ome-point-nhk-says

PM

He's 82 and i think he's been unwell

11:42 am
BE

NHK? That's Japanese telly, no?

PM

Dunno

PM

here it is http://www3.nhk.or.../news/20160713_33/

11:43 am
BE

Yep, the Japanese equivalent of the BBC. One would assume it's not a flier.

PM

NHK has learned that Emperor Akihito has been telling close aides that he wants to abdicate within the next few years and pass the throne to the Crown Prince.

The Emperor is 82 years old. Sources say that he wants to step down before he is too frail to carry out his duties fully.
And they say he has already informed his family members.

Sources say the Imperial Household agency is planning an occasion for the Emperor to address the public.

undefined
11:45 am
BE

Brief word about Abu Dhabi health reform, I think.

BE

Which I'll wager is a subject to excite the readers.

PM

er, ok

11:45 am
PM

What's the latest?

BE

This is a symptom of having Mediclinic in the FTSE 100 and NMC in the mid caps, for no reason anyone can explain adequately.

PM

(Watch it Rabble! We have respect for our new Japanese owners

We are lucky to have them in the current environment...)

11:47 am
BE

.... So, Abu Dhabi's healthcare sector regulator, HAAD, pushed through a load of chances to health insurance charges at the end of last month.

BE

No-one in London noticed.

BE

They only noticed yesterday, as in 12 days later, when Mediclinic and NMC sold off.

11:49 am
BE

The charges were in place on July 1st. Market doesn't pick up on it until July 12th.This is what happens when you have stocks listing in places entirely divorced from where they operate.

BE

Anyway, here's Jefferies to talk us through the changes to Abu Dhabi health regulator's Thiqa and Basic segment of insurance claims.

BE

Thiqa plan holders will now have to pay 20% of the cost of treatment if received in a private hospital vs. full coverage previously. For treatment outside Abu Dhabi, providing the service is offered within Abu Dhabi, the plan will only cover 50% of the cost vs. 90% previously. The number of IVF treatments available to Thiqa patients at private hospitals was also cut to one per year from three previously, the number of procedures at government hospitals is unaffected. Basic plans are affected in two ways; firstly those over 40 will now have to pay up to 50% of their plan premium, the exact amount to be agreed with their respective employer. Secondly, expat employees will have to pay 50% of the premium for dependents (spouse and three children under 18).

11:50 am
BE

It continues .............

BE

Although headline IVF changes look bad - the detail suggests otherwise. NMC is growing its IVF business by opening 5 new centres. Fakih IVF is the largest IVF player in the UAE with c.35% market share and above average success rate at c.70%; we suspect public sector success rates are not so high. We are concerned that the public sector doesn't have the capacity to cope with the expected increased burden following the proposals given 50% of the 20,000 cycles of treatment needed are already carried out abroad; patients would then be penalised by the 50% copay. Assuming 1.5-2 cycles per pregnancy and a 3-6m recovery period suggests the 1x a year private sector cap is not too onerous, especially as pre-cycle treatment is not impacted by this change.

BE

Risk from Basic segment changes most likely to impact population growth. With the increased burden on Basic patients to pay for their healthcare premiums, which in the UAE are mandatory, we see no changes to the way the healthcare system is utilised. That said, the changes are likely to be perceived as a "tax" which could lower Abu Dhabi's attractiveness as a place to work, though these costs aren't material. This could have some impact on long-term volumes, though we note NMC has already made progress in expanding beyond the UAE. We note, that despite Thiqa patients comprising c.15% of NMC's Abu Dhabi hospital business, they are only c.7%-8% patient volumes. Given NMC's large Dubai business, this equates to c.10% of its hospital business.

11:51 am
BE

They reckon a 1.7% hit to 2017 EBITDA for NMC.

BE

And see the Khalifa City project -- NMC's flagship -- unaffected.

NMC Health PLC (NMC:LSE): Last: 1,179, up 59 (+5.27%), High: 1,190, Low: 1,108, Volume: 125.89k
11:52 am
PM

All useful detail Bryce

Mediclinic International PLC (MDC:LSE): Last: 1,076, up 16 (+1.51%), High: 1,079, Low: 1,047, Volume: 288.28k
BE

Has there ever been a FTSE 100 stock people care less about than Mediclinic? I've simply never heard it mentioned.

11:53 am
undefined

The day started and ended badly, arriving in a suit and tie in a heavy storm and a sweltering 30 degrees. (Reasons to be cheerful: the day before was the hottest in July for decades). Then up at 3.00am in great excitement only to see France lose the Euro 2016 final.

ASSET ALLOCATION
TALKING POINTS
| JULY 13, 2016 |
Dear Paul Murphy

Please click on the link below to access our latest report:
DISTRIB_PERM_PDF_BLUE Talking Points - Postcard from Hong Kong (A. Bokobza) (1p)

Alain Bokobza is visiting clients in Asia this week. Having begun his trip in Hong Kong he is now en route for Seoul.

Dear Investor,

The day started and ended badly, arriving in a suit and tie in a heavy storm and a sweltering 30 degrees. (Reasons to be cheerful: the day before was the hottest in July for decades). Then up at 3.00am in great excitement only to see France lose the Euro 2016 final.

The first Hong Kong investors we met with had two things on their minds. Firstly, can emerging market assets continue to provide a safety net with extra carry? Our answer was yes, as the market is repricing the Fed's interest rate policy. We particularly like local currency bonds with the notable exception of Asia (China, Korea) as we expect currencies in this region to continue to fall (see here for CNY). Secondly, Europe after Brexit? Nobody argued against the view that 1.20/1.25 is the next target for GBP/USD (and for the FTSE100 to outperform accordingly). An unanswered question (so sorry!) came from my British passport-holding, Australian-born colleague: will he still be allowed to work at SG's Paris head office without too much red tape?

On our next stop we fielded questions on the European agenda, and in particular the necessity of recapitalising Italian banks by up to €40bn. We think adapting the bail-in rules is unavoidable, otherwise a bail-in could well trigger another European crisis. That said, we think the politicians could take some time before deciding on an ‘opt out' for Italy as retail money has been buying those bonds. European banks, credit (Cocos) and equity markets will clearly be highly sensitive to this decision, when it comes.

Even if I have the great good fortune to live in Paris's historic Latin Quarter, I feel distinctly impoverished when I look at Hong Kong property prices.

PM

Had we been organised, we could've noted the UBS upgrade of Foxtons below the waffle about housebuilders.

Too late for that though, so let's note it now instead.

BE

One of those evidence lab pieces. Likes Foxtons, doesn't like Purplebricks.

11:58 am
BE

We launch coverage of the UK estate agent sector. Online-only agents are structurally
altering the landscape of the sector, and are gaining significant market share as
consumer awareness and willingness to consider using them grows. Conventional
agents most able to differentiate to justify a premium price will be most successful in
withstanding and we place Foxtons (initiate at Buy) and Savills (Buy) in this bracket. In
contrast we see Countrywide as most at risk from this shift, with pressure on
commissions over the last six years indicative of its limited ability to respond to online
competition. However, recent share price weakness on the back of the UK Leave vote
means that this is captured in the valuation and we initiate at Neutral. We initiate at
Sell on Purplebricks, as the valuation looks stretched given execution risks on growth.

BE

We conducted a UBS Evidence Lab survey of 2,500 potential home buyers/sellers and
owners to assess the consumer perception of online/hybrid estate agents and have web
mined over 46 million data points to analyse share progression. The survey shows
online agents enjoy significant consumer awareness (45% of respondents had heard of
Purplebricks) and it suggested a significantly greater likelihood of consumers using an
online agent in the future. Over 80% of respondents suggested a saving of £1000
would prompt them to use an online agent; we estimate that the current online saving
for an "average" house sale is over £2000.

BE

The focus of our UBS Evidence Lab work is on the longer term structural evolution of
the estate agent market. However, we cannot ignore the risks of near term market
volatility as a result of the EU referendum result, given the uncertainty surrounding the
UK economic outlook and potential impact on the housing market. We forecast UK
wide housing transactions down -6% in 2016 and -5% in 2017, and a greater 2017
impact in London of -10%. In addition, we estimate a peak to trough fall in house
prices of 10% from July 2016 (equating to UK house prices +1.5% in 2016, -7% in
2018).
